factoid: A battle is won by those who firmly resolve to win it.
Our side lost the battle at Austerlitz.
The French army's losses were almost equal to our army's losses.
Our side said to itself early that it was losing the battle.
Our side lost the battle.
Our side said so because it had nothing to fight for there.
Our side wanted to get away from the battlefield as soon as possible.
Our side said “We’ve lost, so let us run,” and it ran.
If our side had not said that until the evening, something might not have happened.
Tomorrow our side will not say it.
Our side talks about its position: the left flank is weak and the right flank is too extended.
That is nonsense; there is nothing of that kind.
What awaits our side tomorrow?
There are a hundred million most diverse chances that will be decided instantly by whether our army’s men or the enemy army’s men run or do not run.
Whether this man or that man is killed also matters.
All that is being done at present is only play.
Those men with whom you have ridden round the position do not help matters but hinder.
Those men are only concerned with their own petty interests.
Pierre reproached at such a moment.
Prince Andrew repeated at such a moment.
To them it is only a moment affording opportunities to undermine a rival and obtain an extra cross or ribbon.
For Prince Andrew tomorrow means this: a Russian army of a hundred thousand and a French army of a hundred thousand have met to fight.
The side that fights more fiercely and spares itself least will win.
Whatever happens and whatever muddles those at the top may make, our side shall win tomorrow’s battle.
Tomorrow, happen what may, our side shall win.
That is the truth, the real truth, said Timókhin.
Who would spare himself now?
The soldiers in Timókhin’s battalion would not drink their vodka.
The day is not for that.
All were silent.
The officers rose.
Prince Andrew went out of the shed with the officers, giving final orders to the adjutant.
After they had gone, Pierre approached Prince Andrew and was about to start a conversation.
They heard the clatter of three horses’ hoofs on the road not far from the shed.
Prince Andrew recognized Wolzogen and Clausewitz accompanied by a Cossack.
They rode close by continuing to converse.
Prince Andrew involuntarily heard these words: “The war must be extended widely. I cannot sufficiently commend that view.”
Clausewitz said: “The only aim is to weaken the enemy, so of course one cannot take into account the loss of private individuals.”
The other agreed “Oh, no.”
Prince Andrew said “Extend widely!” with an angry snort when they had ridden past.
In that “extend” were Prince Andrew’s father, son, and sister, at Bald Hills.
That is all the same to Prince Andrew.
Those German gentlemen will not win the battle tomorrow but will only make all the mess they can.
Those German gentlemen have nothing in their heads but theories not worth an empty eggshell.
Those German gentlemen haven’t in their hearts the one thing needed tomorrow: that which Timókhin has.
Those German gentlemen have yielded up all Europe to Timókhin.
Those German gentlemen have now come to teach us.
Fine teachers.
Pierre asked: “So you think our side shall win tomorrow’s battle?”
